title: 115_hr4539
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Plymouth 400th Anniversary Commemorative Coin Act of 2017". The Congress recognizes the significance of the 400th anniversary of the Pilgrims' arrival in Massachusetts in 1620, the signing of the Mayflower Compact, and the founding of Plymouth Colony. This anniversary will highlight the cultural contributions and traditions that shaped the United States through the interaction of the Wampanoag and English peoples. The Pilgrims and the Mayflower have become symbols of freedom and law. The indigenous Wampanoag people played a significant role in the Pilgrims' arrival in Massachusetts in 1620, including their assistance in the first shared harvest. The Mayflower Compact, signed before the Pilgrims landed in Plymouth, was a cornerstone for self-governance in the New World and influenced the Constitution of the United States. The story of the Wampanoag people, the Pilgrims, and the Mayflower are iconic symbols representing freedom, family, law, and justice. Today, people from around the world visit Massachusetts to see the sights of the first landing in Provincetown, early exploration of the New World along Cape Cod, and the ultimate landing and settlement in Plymouth. There are over 20,000,000 descendants worldwide tracing their ancestry back to the Mayflower passengers arriving in 1620. Massachusetts is home to two federally recognized Indian Tribes - the Wampanoag Tribe of Gay Head (Aquinnah) and the Mashpee Wampanoag Tribe. In 2009, Plymouth 400, Inc. was established to commemorate the Plymouth 400th anniversary with themes of exploration, innovation, immigration, self-governance, religious freedom, and thanksgiving. Plymouth 400, Inc. will lead efforts for a commemorative coin series and postage stamps to mark the 400th anniversary of Plymouth Colony in 2020. The proceeds from the coin sales will fund national observances in 2020 and 2021, including events like the signing of the Mayflower Compact and interactions with the Wampanoag people. The curr_chunk is about interactions with the indigenous Wampanoag people during the period of the Plymouth Colony. The curr_chunk focuses on coin specifications. The Secretary of the Treasury will mint and issue $5 gold coins, $1 silver coins, and half-dollar clad coins with specific weights, diameters, and compositions. The coins minted under this Act will be legal tender and considered numismatic items under specific sections of title 31, United States Code. SEC. 4. DESIGN OF COINS. Design Requirements for the coins minted under this Act include being emblematic of the landing and settlement of Plymouth Colony, the signing of the Mayflower Compact, and the role of the indigenous Wampanoag Tribes. Each coin must have a value designation, the year "2020" inscribed, and include words like "Liberty", "In God We Trust", "United States of America", and "E Pluribus Unum". The design will be selected by the Secretary after consulting with Plymouth 400, Inc. The organizations involved in the design review process for the coins minted under this Act include Plymouth 400, Inc., the General Society of Mayflower Descendants, the Mashpee Wampanoag Tribe, the Wampanoag Tribe of Gay Head (Aquinnah), the Pilgrim Society, Plimoth Plantation, Inc., the Pilgrim Monument and Provincetown Museum, Provincetown 400, the Plymouth Antiquarian Society, the Massachusetts Cultural Council, and the Massachusetts Historical Society. The design will be reviewed by the Citizens Coinage Advisory Committee. SEC. 5. ISSUANCE OF COINS.

Coins minted under this Act will be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities from a single United States Mint facility during a 1-year period starting January 1, 2020.

SEC. 6. SALE OF COINS. SEC. 6. SALE OF COINS.

The coins will be sold by the Secretary at a price including face value, surcharge, and design costs. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will receive a reasonable discount. All sales of coins issued under this Act will include surcharges: $35 for the $5 coin, $10 for the $1 coin, and $5 for the half-dollar coin. Surcharges received will be distributed with 30% going to Plymouth 400, Inc. to support commemorations and local historical preservation. The surcharges from sales of coins will be distributed with 30% going to local historical preservation, tribal, and cultural organizations for educating the public about the settlement of 1620 and supporting their continued existence. Another 30% will go to the General Society of Mayflower Descendants for various purposes including facility restoration, research library funding, academic study support, and restoration of the National Pilgrim Memorial Meetinghouse. The surcharges from coin sales will be distributed to various organizations for educational and preservation purposes. This includes support for the Mashpee Wampanoag Tribe, the Wampanoag Tribe of Gay Head (Aquinnah), and the Pilgrim Society for the stewardship of historical materials. The surcharges from coin sales will support the historic 1824 museum building, digitization program, new museum website, improvements to exhibition galleries with focus on Wampanoag history, and educational programs including a museum internship program. 5 percent of the surcharges will go to Plimoth Plantation Inc. for educational programs and exhibits. The surcharges from coin sales will support educational programs and exhibits at the Museum about the 17th-century history of America, including the Mayflower, Pilgrims, Mayflower Compact, and Native people. 5 percent of the surcharges will go to Pilgrims' First Landing Park, Inc. to educate people about the Wampanoag people and Pilgrims, and maintain historical markers related to the events of 1620 and 1621. The Comptroller General of the United States will have the right to audit the organization's financial records. The Secretary of the Treasury may issue guidance to limit the number of commemorative coin programs issued in a calendar year to avoid exceeding the annual limit. Additionally, certain organizations are exempt from a matching requirement under title 31, United States Code. The organizations mentioned in subsection (b) are exempt from certain provisions of title 31, United States Code, regarding surcharges paid under this Act. The Secretary must ensure that minting coins under this Act does not cost the US Government and that no funds are disbursed until all costs are recovered by the Treasury.
